sub_title: Dutch to English translator (native-speaker), owner of Chapter & Verse Translation Services and writer of epic, mapping-themed mountain stories
summary:
English native-speaker translator - with over 30 years' experience of translating Dutch into English - working in a diversity of fields: law, education, journalism, sales & marketing, human resources, transport, travel & tourism, culture & media, general business correspondence.

Teaching English as a Foreign Language

projects:
[{'title': 'Mapping the Mountains: the book', 'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2019}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'In our modern world getting lost is almost impossible. Our mobile devices allow us to navigate the world with pinpoint accuracy. It was not always thus. In order to define geographical relationships, over time humans developed techniques through astronomy and triangulation. On the basis of measurements these relationships could be recorded on paper in the form of a map. The more sophisticated these techniques became, the more accurate these maps could be drawn, with navigation likewise becoming more safe and secure. Ironically, we have now reached a point where the data we have amassed can be handled and processed so that we no longer need maps to move from place to place.

The first Mapping the Mountains exhibition was held in Heerlen, the Netherlands from 1 November 2019 to 29 February 2020.

Historically, the starting point for exhibition content was marked by the development of mapping techniques from the 17th century onwards.
As well as shining the spotlight on the early pioneers, such as the Cassinis, Everest and Dufour, the principles on which their cartographic goals were achieved were also presented, for example, astronomy, trigonometry and depiction of relief. 
The exhibition also explored the contribution made by mountaineers to mountain mapping, either through their individual efforts or under the aegis of the nascent alpine clubs in the late 19th century. 
Mapping the Mountains – the book

A book is the most logical follow-up, even if it were to simply be a catalogue to accompany the exhibition. But the fact that there was already a substantial body of text (and other material) available, gave rise to a realisation that this could be added to and built on, but revolving around the existing exhibition framework.

Essentially, the book will tell the same story, but more comprehensively and in greater depth and breadth. Whilst retaining the same framework, in terms of themes and (mountain) regions, a great deal of new material will be added.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Andrew', 'last_name': 'Davies', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Dutch to English translator (native-speaker), owner of Chapter & Verse Translation Services and writer of epic, mapping-themed mountain stories '}]}, {'title': 'Mapping the Mountains exhibition', 'date': {'start': {'month': 11, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}, 'end': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}}, 'description': 'Mountaineering would not have been possible had it not been for mapmakers, yet cartographic development was not driven by a quest to discover extreme mountain environments, but born of a necessity to understand more about the world we live in. This was especially true in the Age of Enlightenment when unexplored (and unexploited) areas of the earth were opening up to the great European powers.
 
The exhibition traces the history of mountain cartography since the 17th century. From la Carte générale de la France, produced by the Cassinis, a dynasty of cartographers who were the first to make wide-scale use of advanced triangulation techniques; the Golden Age of mountaineering,  when Edward Whymper would not have been able to travel so widely in the Alps had it not been for Guillaume Henri Dufour, responsible for the first ever detailed map of Switzerland; to the mapping of the very highest mountains when Sir George Everest carried out the Great Trigonometrical Survey of India, culminating in the charting  of the Himalayas. Later, mountaineers - often under the auspices of Alpine Clubs – would also make their contribution to mapmaking and to this day the Deutsche Alpenverein still produces some of the very best maps of the Eastern Alps.
 
Some argue that modern mountaineering started with the unsung military surveyors who slogged their way to almost insurmountable summits in all weathers carrying heavy measuring equipment, so that the land could be accurately mapped and so that we can enjoy the freedom of the great outdoors today.
', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Andrew', 'last_name': 'Davies', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Dutch to English translator (native-speaker), owner of Chapter & Verse Translation Services and writer of epic, mapping-themed mountain stories '}]}]
